{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3152528,"name":null,"username":"Raven_Robotics","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/raven_robotics/{size}/184532_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-25T15:40:01.681Z","cooked":"

We are using MK4 swerve kits for our robot this year. We want create a function that takes a distance and meters and moves the robot that far in a given direction. To do this, we need an equation to convert the drive encoder output to a distance in meters. Any ideas on what equation to use?

For reference, we are using the built-in encoders on the Neo motors (RelativeEncoder class), CANSparkMax motor controllers, and Java. I don’t need the full implementation of the idea, just the conversion equation.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2023-02-25T15:40:01.681Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":149,"reads":65,"readers_count":64,"score":758.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":428066,"topic_slug":"converting-drive-motor-encoder-output-to-meters-swerve","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57040,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/converting-drive-motor-encoder-output-to-meters-swerve/428066/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3152626,"name":"Michael Jansen","username":"mjansen4857","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjansen4857/{size}/201972_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-25T18:09:45.589Z","cooked":"

General conversion equation:

metersPerPulse = gearRatio * (Math.PI * wheelDiameter) / pulsesPerRotation;
wheelPositionMeters = encoderPosition * metersPerPulse (you should probably just use the set conversion factor methods on the encoder object)

For NEOs, pulsesPerRotation = 42
Mk4 wheelDiameter = Units.inchesToMeters(4.0)

Gear ratio:
1.0 / 8.14 for L1
1.0 / 6.75 for L2
1.0 / 6.12 for L3
1.0 / 5.14 for L4

Plus, you need the effective wheel circumference. The diameter is -roughly- 4" so circumference is -roughly- 4" X 3.1415. HOWEVER, you need to calibrate this if you are doing any sort of precise work.

To do that, you need a long section of carpet (as long as you have available). Put in your decent estimate of the distance per revolution. Put a weighted box against the back of your robot. Measure from the box to something easy to easy to measure to on your robot; write it down. Command the robot to SLOWLY go a specified distance (based on your estimated circumference). Measure again. Subtract the starting number. Adjust your distance per rev based on the ratio of the commanded motion to actual motion.

The issue is the little fingers on the tread reach into the carpet, so the effective diameter of the wheel actually depends on what you are driving on. On concrete your bot will drive farther than carpet. Assuming it doesn’t slip, of course!

Things may be easier if you use YAGSL I develop and test it with Neo’s and 1466 develops it for falcons.
